comments.text:
+MofoWoW Technically it's still moving at the same speed, it's just that 
the photons are bouncing off of atoms and taking longer to get to point A 
to point B. It's just like going through a zigzag street will take long 
that going through a straight street even if both cars are going the same 
speed.
comments.author: Deliciousbutter

comments.text:
+MofoWoW yup you are right. i'd also like explain the paradox here. yes, 
the light would be 'stuck' in the blackhole, not able to move at all. Yet 
it still travels at the same speed, 299,792,458 m/s. How can this be so? 
Simple explanation: Time Stops; Time dilation occurs to such a large extent 
that even the fastest objects appear not to move.

Distance = Speed x Time = 299,792,458 m/s x 0s = 0m
Thus, light can still be travelling at 299,792,458 m/s even though it is 
not even moving an inch.

For more info, do look up 'time dilation' at 'event horizons'
Cheers :)
comments.author: maverick lim

comments.text:
+OmegaA1000 You make a good argument; however, it's a sophistry. Light that 
is stuck in a black hole moves at the same speed as light outside of a 
black hole. Light can't escape because bending of space-time is to great to 
overcome, not because it's moving slower. I'd also like to point out that 
the universal constant is the speed of light in a vacuum, not just the 
speed of light. Light does move slower in water, for instance.

pass through dense materials like our atmosphere; just think of it like how 
headlights may not be seen on a foggy morning. Shorter wavelengths are 
difficult to see, but penetrate materials easier than light of longer 
wavelengths; that's why infrared heat signatures can be viewed through 
solid objects.

comments.text:
I remember the first time I ever really thought about my mortality. I was 
in my room, it was night, though I could still see the dark outline of 
everything in it via the slivers of light of the moon passing through my 
window shades. I remember thinking that I was going to die someday, that I 
would be gone. That the world would carry on without me. Only living 
through the memories of people I've had an impact on. It was a scary 
feeling, like that I wouldn't matter, my very existence didn't matter if 
one day I was just going to die. But then I thought, "No", I do matter. of 
all the possible people that could have existed, it was me who was brought 
into this world. Me, who's able to think, create and enjoy this world, this 
wonderful world of ours. It's my time to live, my time to grow, and I'm 
going to damn well enjoy as much of it as I can. And then I sort of lost my 
passion and fell asleep because it was like 4 in the morning and I was 
really tired.

comments.text:
Out atmosphere isn't transparent. The light of the sun makes it bright blue 
during the day, which makes it impossible to see any other stars. At night, 
city lights brighten up the sky until they sky itself is brighter than the 
stars, and so we don't see them.

It's not really because our atmosphere is scattering or blocking the light 
of the stars. If that was the case then even in dark places we wouldn't be 
able to see them. Our atmosphere does distort light entering it slightly, 
but that happens constantly, and to the same extent extent all over the 
world.

Don't worry about your eyes either. It's a question of relative brightness, 
there are no eyes that can pick out a dim star behind a bright sky.

Also, to comment on another topic that came up: without an atmosphere earth 
would be like a lot like the moon. Pretty hot on the side facing the sun, 
and really cold on the side facing away. The changes would be very extreme 
because having an atmosphere catches light and distributes heat throughout 
the surface of the planet. When there's no atmosphere, all of that light is 
caught or reflected by the surface, so it will get pretty hot, pretty 
quickly. But because the surface doesn't flow and distribute that heat, the 
side facing away will remain very cold.

Also! Atmosphere or no, no matter far away you are, the sun will always 
cast light over the all of the half of a celestial body that faces it. 
Imagine the light as a sphere expanding concentrically from the sun. When 
the surface of that sphere reaches you, it will cover the entire day side 
planet, not just a small part of it.
comments.author: Matt Watson

comments.text:
+sam witwicky The Ozone layers are protecting us from the massive 
radiation. Our Atmosphere is scattering the light, but the photons (light 
and radiation) would, like Kaitlyn Amanda mentioned, destroy us (while we

screwed.

Red shifting effects it, as well as particles (like gas and dust) between 
us and the light, I also think there is some sort of law which makes it 
harder to see; In your first comment you mentioned your phones screen 
perfectly fine in the light, the reason is because your phones screen is 
reasonably bright compared to the lights in the room, it's probably also 
quite close to you, but if you compare with an already dimmed source of of 
light (which is light years away), a city's light could drown it out; take 
this analogy, imagine a phone screen that is dimmed and you have a jug of 
water that has had sugar dissolved in it, in front of it, not so easy to 
see now is it? Or just dim your phone screen in the sunlight (or any bright 
light).

comments.author: Danial Loganathan

comments.text:
Brightness is measured in lumens, which is basically the intensity of 
photons in a certain area. The farther away you are, the less chance at any 
point in time a photon will reach that set area. Eventually (though humans 
process this as darkness) any light source would become a sort of "strobe"- 
each blink would represent a photon. The higher the intensity of something, 
the higher the concentration of particles received from a distance.

huge ruler, then no. However, there are some smart things you can do.

Take this example, you can measure the height of a tree without using a 
ruler. You just require the distance from it and the angle at which you 
need to look up to see its top. The same works in reverse if you know its 
height, you can measure the distance to it. This is called triangulation.

Through several similar steps (and many other), people have been able to 
determine an approximate radius for Earth's orbit around the sun. If you 
know this value, and you know the angle at which you look at the star, then 
you have the distance to it.

However, this is accurate only up till apprx 400 light years. Further than 
this you can use the color spectrum of the star by comparing it to the 
color spectrum of stars of known distances. This allows us to get its 
brightness, which we can use to determine its distance.

top_comment.text:
This subject ( black holes, super novas, outer space in general...) has 
always interested me. Not because of what we know about them, but because 
of how little we know and yet claim to have knowledge of. Its not 
scientific really, considering its all theoretical. However scientists and 
theorists alike speak on these subjects like we've been there, and yet we 
aren't even minutely close enough to them to draw any kind of reasonable 
conclusion. Its glorified guess work. And with all the math and observation 
we have, its more like a shot in the dark. Let me put it his way (also a 
very unscientific approach): let's say the earth was completely transparent 
for a moment, and a hunter was able to look through its crust and core with 
an incredibly high powered scope to the other side. He would see another 
country, and its people going about their daily business. With no sound, 
and a poor perspective, he could make some pretty good guesses at what's 
happening in that country only to travel there later and realize he was 
completely wrong about what he saw. Even though he had convinced himself 
and maybe a few others with what he saw. The difference with the hunter and 
modern science, is that we have the luxary of not knowing for certain, and 
therefore not really being able to be proven wrong. Scientist often (not 
necessarily purposefully) mislead their peers because the information is 
almost too incredible to dispute. Black holes sound like this amazing 
thing, but we have truly have little or no knowledge on them aside from 
what we can observe with our bare eyes. And yet for some reason, we claim 
to know all of this bizarre information based on very basic observations 
and experiments that cant be proven. Its kind of naive if you ask me. Its 
like looking at an ant with a magnifying glass once, seeing it carry a 
large cracker on its back and just assuming it must be magic supporting the 
cracker. In reality, we only know what we know about the ant or any other 
animal or thing in our earth through thorough testing and scrutinizing 
examination. But at the same time, we blindly accept everything that is 
spoon fed to us about existence and the cosmos. Again, it contradicts the 
very characteristics of humanity that allow us to survive. Common sense 
people.Think about it YouTube:)﻿
top_comment.author: Benjamin Battaglia

comments.text:
Black holes and supernovae do in fact exist. Quasars and blazars *are* 
supermassive black holes. Most of what we know of black holes comes from 
mathematics. There is also one at the center of our galaxy, named 
Sagittarius A*. As for supernovae, we've actually seen them happen. Ever 
seen a picture of the Crab Nebula? That's the aftermath of a supernova. 
(Picture: http://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/0/00/Crab_Nebula.jpg
)

I think you're a bit confused. Theories are not guesses, they are facts. 
All of this *is* scientific.

If you don't trust what it being told to you, there are plenty of articles 
and peer reviewed scientific papers to look at, evidence included.

comments.text:
+fordcabriogt The event horizon of a simple static black hole, 
or Schwarzschild black hole, is believed to form a perfect sphere. In this 
case, it's not the "dark part" of the black hole that forms a disc; it's 
the non-dark parts, the matter, which forms the accretion disc.

Then there's the question of whether charged or violently rotating black 
holes can lead to other matter configurations. That's a discussion in 
itself that I'm not interested in participating  in.

thing that has the crazy mass) being a single dot at the center.

comments.author: tysej4

comments.text:
+tysej4 Hawking radiation is emitted by quantum tunnelling. Let's say you 
have 2 specific particles in a black hole. Over time, through quantum 
tunnelling, one of these particles will find itself outside of the black 
hole, which means that the black hole itself loses that particle's worth of 
mass. 

While the gravitational attraction of a black hole is truly immense, in the 
world of quantum mechanics, traditional gravity doesn't "work". To date, 
there is no definitive theory on how gravity works on a quantum scale. But 
quantum tunnelling is better understood in comparison.

Over timescales useful to us (thousands-millions of years) this loss is 
pretty much considered to be almost nothing. However, over a timespan that 
would be difficult to imagine or comprehend, it will add up and eventually 
the black hole will evaporate into nothing.

This is a very simple and non-technical explanation of the phenomenon.
comments.author: MethosTR

Black holes don't collapse in on themselves, they're already a singularity. 
That means it's a very small point of infinite density. At the point you 
reach infinite density, it is logically impossible to collapse down any 
further.

Black holes release something call Hawking radiation, which eats away at 
their mass. If a black hole doesn't have a continuous source of new mass to 
overcome the effects of Hawking radiation, then they'll eventually 
dissipate completely.

Dear, Michael.
If there are negative degrees Celsius and negative degrees Fahrenheit, is 
it possible for their to be negative degrees kelvin if the kelvin scale's 0 
is absolute 0?﻿
top_comment.author: Jericho Kratzburg

comments.text:
he did a leanback about temperatures you should check that out. but

comments.author: Awi

comments.text:
+asthmaticrhino
Well explained!!!
comments.author: Awi

comments.text:
+Jericho Kratzburg I too am no expert, but I recall a Sixty Symbols video 
where they talked about the concept of negative Kelvin temperature, and it 
isn't really a measurement of heat but a transfer of energy. The gist is 
this: usually heat flows from something that is hotter to something that is 
colder. There are special instances in which this can be subverted (the 
most common of which is to point a laser at something, I think was said) 
and heat goes into the hotter thing.

Something in negative Kelvin is not colder than absolute zero, it is 
actually a hot temperature.
comments.author: Gruncival

comments.text: thank you ^^
comments.author: Jericho Kratzburg

comments.text:
I believe he briefly went over something like this in a previous episode 
but as far as negative temperature go, you'd have to watch a video from a 
physicist. 0°K is absolute zero. It is possible to have "negative Kelvin" 
but it refers to energy rather than temperature, it's actually pretty hard 
to explain. Technically something at negative Kelvin would be the hottest 
temperatures attainable but nothing can be at or below absolute zero.
comments.author: willgtl

comments.text:
I'm not Vsauce Michael, but I'll answer. Simply, no. Complete absolute zero 
would mean that fundamental particles themselves would stop vibrating, and 
we don't exactly know what would happen as a result of that. Within a hair 
of absolute zero a strange thing happens with matter, it becomes something 
called a Bose-Einstein Condensate, where quantum effects are discernible on 
a macro scale.

+Shahlan Saleem Well, your quote of the Quran isn't quite correct. The 
excerpt is meant to read: "it is we who have built heaven", not "built the 
universe" as you have quoted, therefore everything else in your point has 
no value towards that part of the discussion.

Going back to some early points made by others:

With the way the world is right now could you truly say that in the 
possibility that god exists, that he is benevolent?...I see the word evil 
typed a few times...we are all agreed that evil exists right? Well, is god 
able to get rid of evil, or, if he is, is he willing?
If he is able, but not willing, he is malevolent
If he is not able, but willing, he is not omnipotent
if he is able, and willing, then why is there evil?
or, if he is neither able, nor willing, then why call him god?

I also see faith described above by several people, so I bring you a quote 
by AronRa
"We either base our 'confidence' on reason (evident probabilities, past 
experience, competence, etc) or we base our beliefs on faith, which is 
blind by definition. Faith is the most dishonest position it is possible to 
have, because it is an assertion of stoic conviction that is assumed 
without reason and defended against all reason. If you have to believe it 
on faith, you have no reason to believe it at all."

Also, above you quoted the bible, saying that it was evidence for humans 
not being animals. When, in fact, the bible is evidence for nothing apart 
from the fact that a few people from the 1100's were literate.  Because, 
that's exactly what it is.  It is a story written in the 12th century of 
supposed events that happened over a millenia before. Also,you were quoting 
the bible about the beginning, which is what, supposedly 6000 years ago? 
You can't believe that to be true, being written 5000 years after the 
'fact'. We are closer to the time in which the bible was written than they 
are to the events they are writing about! Surely, it's obvious that the 
bible cannot be used as harbingers of fact--more so, neither can any other 
religious writings such as your Quran, or the Jews' Torah, because that's 
all any of them are. They are stories written by people many years after 
the events written about.

Also, I want to tell you that if anyone talks to you as though they are 
better simply because they don't believe in "fairy tales" (sorry).  Most 
atheists are not bigoted towards religious people--being good is not 
inherent to religion.  Morals come from basic empathy, which stems from 
human interaction. So don't believe at all that without god we are without 
good.  Likewise, I stress, very firmly, that anyone who reads this that is 
religious: Don't be bigoted towards anyone due to ANYTHING, including their 
religion, or lack thereof, because, truly, doesn't the bible preach more 
than anything to simply be a good person?

comments.text:
I think all of you people suggesting "blackout day" or similar ideas don't 
know what you're actually talking about. Like that +justme man, whose 
comment I can't reply to for some strange reason.

You do realize that your lights-out-day will cause severe problems with 
electric infrastructure, and specifically, power plants? Power plants 
cannot be turned off with a press of a button, and excess energy produced 
has to go somewhere and workers at power plants have to pull off an 
insanely hard job at managing this situation, when there's a sudden drop in 
electricity demand.

Not sure about overboard, but here in Poland we have something called "An 
Hour For Earth", a tradition done by stupid people to "save the earth" by 
once every year shutting down all electric devices and lights in a house 
for one hour... which causes serious problems and gives severe headaches to 
workers at electric plants, who have to work their asses off to prevent 
generators and power lines from melting down. Hilarious, since people who 
do this actually INCREASE CO2 emission, since during that time they will 
use candles... which produce CO2, and meanwhile the power plants do NOT 
reduce their CO2 emission.

comments.text:
Smaller, more localized sources of light pollution can also affect your 
viewing. Is there e.g. a stadium, or a substation near your home? 
Facilities like these employ powerful floodlights, so you might want to 
move away from them. Other factors also have an influence, like how clear 
the air is. The best time of year to view is at the end of your rainy 
season, when rainfall has cleared the air of dust, but clouds are no longer 
an issue. Keep these things in mind, and good luck. ;)

comments.text:
You're welcome. I didn't read any sarcasm in your question, I'm just bad at 
phrasing. I just meant to let you know that when you said "Ah~ that 
explains it!", it actually doesn't explain anything besides how you got 
your numbers confused. 
If you had your numbers right, it is still a good question (we can see way 
farther than 14 billion light years), and my comment was meant to answer 
that (which is why I said your point instead of your question, because your 
question is flawed with mixed up numbers)
comments.author: Daniel

comments.text:
+Daniel thank you for your special contribution but it was an honest 
question, I wasn't trying to make a point.  Try reading without imagining 
sarcasm in the tone.
comments.author: James Forestieri

comments.text:
Even if the universe were 5 billion years old, we could still see light as 
far away as 9 billion light years. This is due to the expansion of space 
itself. The special theory of relativity does not specify that space can't 
expand faster than the speed of light, but that nothing can travel in space 
faster than the speed of light. So not only did you get your numbers mixed 
up, but your entire point is also wrong.

captions.text: Hey, Vsauce. Michael here.
This symbol, commonly called a Yin Yang
symbol, is a taijitu meaning diagram
of the supreme ultimate. The principal

of Yin and yang, opposites existing in
harmony,

is associated with ancient Chinese
philosophy.

But the very first use of the iconography,
the classic symbol,

actually comes from a shield pattern
used by the ancient
Romans seven hundred years before its first

known use in China.
A connection between the two

has yet to be found.
Regardless of who came up with it first,

the symbol was a bright idea.
But what's the brightest object in the entire universe?
Well, apparent magnitude.

Commonly used when stargazing refers to
how bright an object
appears to us, say, when looking up from Earth.

It depends on Earth-centric factors,
like how close the object is
to our planet. Magnitudes are logarithmic
and arranged like golf, where a smaller number
means a greater brightness. But today
I'm looking for absolute magnitude,

a measure of how bright things all over
the universe near

and far would be if we looked at them
from the same distance.

Absolute magnitude will guide
us to the most blinding
light in the universe, irrespective of it looking faint
to us here on Earth, just because it's far away.
The difference is significant. A 100-watt light bulb

placed closer than 8 centimetres - about
3 inches - from your eye
will appear brighter than the Sun in the sky.
But that's not fair. If you could see the Sun and the bulb

from the same distance, the Sun would be
a septillion times brighter.
That's bright. But the Sun
shines punily compared to the rest of the cosmos.

If you could line the Sun up with
everything else out there,

giving every star and cosmological
phenomenon
a fair chance, the Sun's absolute magnitude
would be 4.8. Not bad. But check out
R136a1. This nuclear fuelled beast isn't
the biggest star in terms of volume but it's 256

times more massive than our Sun.
It's the most massive star
ever found and it's also the brightest.

Remember that lower absolute
magnitudes are brighter.
like our Sun, it is -12.6,
which means it is 8.7 million times brighter
than our own Sun. But R136a1

isn't the brightest thing out there.
When a giant star dies, it explodes violently
in what is known as a supernova
or hypernova. As I mentioned in my video

'How Hot Can It Get?',
supernovas can eject terrifying flashes of

radiation known as gamma ray bursts.
Arguably,

the brightest electromagnetic events in
the universe.
A typical gamma-ray burst releases as much
energy in a few seconds as our Sun
will release altogether in its entire
10 billion year lifetime. If WR104,
a gamma-ray burst future candidate, directly struck
Earth with such a beam for only 10 seconds
astronomers predict it could deplete 25% of our
ozone layer and lead to mass extinction and starvation.
The largest thermonuclear bomb ever detonated

didn't do anything close to that and it
was exploded right
here, in our atmosphere. Whereas WR104

is eight thousand light years away.
You can't even see it with your naked eye

or a pair of binoculars.
But gamma ray bursts are merely brief
events lasting only a few minutes at most, sometimes
just a matter of milliseconds. If you want the brightest
sustained thing, you'll paradoxically have to look
at the darkest thing. Black holes.
To be fair, dark matter is ostensibly
darker. But because dark matter has been hypothesized
to not even interact with light, with electromagnetism
at all, calling dark matter "not bright"
is kind of like calling your peanut butter sandwich

"a not fast airplane".
It's not really even in the same category.
Black holes, however, do interact with light;
reflecting so little, well, they don't let any
escape, at least not in a form resembling the way
it came in. That's dark.

But the intense energies created by
black holes in the process of eating
things like stars

is anything but dark.
Gas and debris from the stars they eat swirl into
arcipluvian cosmic gallows known as accretion discs

before making their final death plunge
into the black hole.

In the disc, debris spins at unfathomable
speeds, pulled around by a black hole
billions of times more massive

than our Sun.
Friction in the accretion disk generates heat
on a level difficult to fully appreciate.
Just as hot things glow, the disk does too.
So brightly it has its own name.

A quasar.
Quasars shine thousands of times more brightly
than even the brightest stars.
I'm kidding, it's scarier

than that.
Quasars shine thousands of times more brightly
than galaxies containing billions of stars.

The first identified quasar, 3C 273,
has an absolute magnitude
of -26.7, making it
four trillion times brighter than our Sun,

about 100 times more luminous than the
total amount of light produced by the
entire Milky Way. If you put 3C 273

33 light years away from us it would
shine as brightly as our Sun -

a mere 8 light minutes away.
Blocking the brightness of a quasar with the corona

graph reveals that quasars exist in the
centers of galaxies
that are larger than them in area, but are, nonetheless,
drowned out by their light.
Such galactic centres are called active galactic nuclei.

The bulk of their energy spewing forth
in the form of a powerful radiation jet,
the length of which puts even

our solar system to shame.
The visible part of the jet

in this photograph, for instance, is so
long it could stretch from the Sun
to Pluto and back, one-and-a-half million times.

Now, specifically, if a large portion of
this ajected energy heads toward Earth,
it's responsible for what we call a quasar.

But if Earth is right and the active
galactic nucleus' sights,
it's got a scarier name: a blazar.

And it's blazar 3C 454.3 that clocked
in the greatest brightness

ever observed.
At historically high levels of activity it registered in
absolute magnitude of -31.4.
To put the brightness of quasars

in yet another perspective, take a look
at the one hundred thousandth
picture snapped by the Hubble telescope.
This is a star a few hundred light years away.
And this thing looks just about as bright,
but it is a quasar.
9 billion light years away.
Why are quasars so far away?
Well, a quasar is not forever.
They are billions of light years away,

which means the light we receive from
them, the pictures we take of them,

are pictures of things happening
billions of years ago.
They represent a phenomenon more common

early in the universe's history, when
monster black holes hadn't eaten

all the stars around them to fuel their
accretion discs and
before those holes became too fat to be active.
Neil deGrasse Tyson points out that in order to remain
a quasar producer, a black hole must consume
about 10 stars a year. Many
consume more than a thousand stars a year, 600
Earths worth of matter every single minute. The more

stars a black hole consumes,
the larger its event horizon becomes
until, eventually, it no longer shreds stars apart

to fuel an accretion disc.
Instead, it just swallows them whole
in one dimmer, but still terrifying, gulp.

Quasars are some of the most
ancient things in our universe.
If you could teleport instantaneously to one right now

faster than light, it would most likely
no longer be burning. What we see
are just their ghosts. Light that left when they were
active that traveled longer than they could live.
But quasars can still be born. They can even be born
right here, in fact. In my video

'What Will We Miss?' I pointed out that
the Andromeda Galaxy
is headed our way.
In 3 to 5 billion years it will collide
with our own galaxy, the Milky Way. And the collision

could rearrange stars near the
galaxy's central black holes to be consumed,
reigniting a quasar right here, in our galactic backyard.
Funny enough, right now very few of us even see

Andromeda, even though all you
need is your unaided eye.
Light from our cities drowns out the night sky like a

quasar drowns out its host galaxy. Artist
Thierry Cohen mocked up what big cities
would look like if all their lights were
off and the sky above them could be seen
fully. New York, Hong Kong, Shanghai,
Tokyo, Los Angeles. It's beautiful
and rare. In the 1990s,

during a blackout in the city of Los Angeles,
a number of residence

actually called the police they were
afraid of mysterious glowing clouds
hovering above the city. They were seeing
our galaxy for the first time in their lives.
At night, artificial lights allow us to see
what's around us but we lose
what's above us. The brightest places
have the darkest, emptiest skies.

There's Yin and Yang again. A taijitu
has actually been lurking in this video
the entire time.
The brightest things in the universe, quasars,
are caused by the darkest things in the universe -
black holes. The process that unshackles the most light
is caused by the thing that best imprisons it.
And as always,
thanks for watching.

title: What's The Brightest Thing In the Universe?
